name: utricularia-purpurea
country-or-region-of-origin: Eastern Canada, central and eastern U.S.A.
wildlife-value: This plant attracts birds, flies, butterflies, and moths.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
fruit-description: Fruit displays from July to October.
flower-description: Racemes of 1-5 snapdragon-like purple flowers atop naked reddish stems from May to September. 1/3 to Â½ inch long, the lower lip is 3-lobed, white at the base with a spot of yellow in the center. The upper lobe is as wide but shorter. A curved spur is present below the lower lip that is yellowish to white.
leaf-description: Leaves occur in whorls of 5 to 7 with bladders at the tips of leaves. They are branched into slender segments giving it a lacy look. Greenish to brown in color.
stem-description: The stems are submerged and can grow 3 feet long
